The simple answer is that we don't know what dark matter is.  It's an active area of research.  There are lots of people working on this, and lots of experiments trying to solve the problem.  Most commonly, we guess that dark matter is made of particles (like the matter that we can see is), but that it doesn't interact with normal matter, or it interacts so infrequently that we haven't been able to see it yet.  (If a particle doesn't interact with matter, it can pass right through, and you won't know it was ever there.)  But, it interacts with gravity, so we have evidence from lots of different sources that it exists.

Particle physicist here.  Lemme address your Newton/GR question (because it's the easiest).  Newtonian gravity is actually a subset of general relativity, not a separate theory.  In every gravity experiment that we've ever done, general relativity has been able to explain the results.  But, the equations of general relativity are complicated, and you don't want to use the full machinery of GR when you don't have to.  In certain situations (like, where objects are moving at low speeds, and gravitational fields aren't very strong) the equations simplify to Newtonian gravity.  In those cases, you use Newtonian gravity, because it's way, way easier.  So, anything that Newtonian gravity can do, GR can do.  But the reverse is not true.  And, if you want to see a place where particle physicists have more obvious success, check out the magnetic moment of the muon.  ;-)

The of the great late physicists said this about physics:  "Our world is completely composed of jello. When the jello jiggles, you won't notice, because the jello jiggles everything. It jiggles everything except for one parameter, and this is the parameter that allows us to see the jello. We haven't found this parameter, but this is what physics is hunting for. Everyone who practices physics doesn't know it, but this is the ultimate goal of physics: To find that parameter."

At this point they are widely accepted in the scientific community as probably being true.  Of course everything in science is a theory and must, by definition, be falsifiable, so it may turn out that dark matter and/or dark energy are not the correct ways to describe nature.  But at the moment we have good reason to believe they are.  When a theory is generally accepted, we typically don't bother to point out that it is only a theory and may be incorrect; rather, this should be implicitly understood.

My #1 complaint with this series was that the Modern Physics segment of this series was far too short. I do hope they pick this up and built on subjects such as Relativity, Quantum Mechanics, Nuclear Physics, and Cosmology. Nuclear Decay would be a lot easier to explain when the audience understands quantum tunneling. I do also hope they explore fields such as solid-state physics (to explain solar panels, LEDs, and transistors), plasma physics, and even particle physics. It could be a series entirely built off of the concepts of quantum mechanics.  This was a great intro physics series. Bit fast, but enjoyable. I hope to see this continue soon!

It is constantly changing in continuous steps, not in discrete intervals.  We have only been aware of the Hubble parameter for around 100 years. Compare that with the age of the universe, around 14 billion years.  The Hubble parameter changes very slowly relative to human timescales, so for our purposes it is effectively constant when we speak of the universe as it is today.

I think it's important to always question how we come to conclusions maybe we are not measuring galaxies right. We're not sure what caused the Big Bang, that could be a force of physics that still permeates.  I'm just not sure Dark Energy exists.

In neither case should the pencil fly back immediately.  You are in the car that is moving at 80 mph. Therefore you are also moving at 80 mph.  You are holding a pencil, therefore the pencil is also moving at 80 mph.  If you let go of the pencil, it is still moving at 80 mph and therefore at 0 mph relative to the car. It will just drop straight down.  Imagine the perils of airplane travel if this weren't so: you get out of your seat and both feet momentarily leave the ground and you immediately splat yourself against the back wall at 500 mph. Luckily this doesn't happen!

Perhaps, but I think probably not.  We know exactly what new elements would look like: just add some more protons to the nucleus of the heaviest known atom.  The problem with heavier elements is that they are often unstable, meaning they quickly break down into lighter components and are unlikely to be found in much abundance.  Also keep in mind that all the elements that exist in the universe were built up by fusion processes from much lighter elements.  In the very early universe, there was nothing but Hydrogen.  Later this was able to fuse into helium, then some of the helium fused with other hydrogen or helium to form lithium and so on.  Heavy elements almost certainly are not produced in enough abundance to account for the large percentage of matter that dark matter comprises.

You do know that 'dark energy' is not a thing by itself, it's just a term that when placed in the currently accepted theories makes them fit the experimental observations. We still don't known what it is or how to probe it, hence the 'dark'. 'Dark matter', by the way, is also something that when added to currently held theories makes them fit experimental results, but all we know is that it is some kind of matter (or at least something with mass as it interacts gravitationally) that does not interact with electromagnetic radiation (which prompted the whole 'dark' thing with names. You do realize that scientific laws are not something that nature has to obey, they are just something we use to describe what we observe in the universe. The universe itself couldn't care less about all the mathematical formalism we use to describe it. I suggest you visit Sixty Symbols channel and watch the dark matter (v=77yXhAibQp4) and dark energy (v=IJYDcXZMe9c) videos.

Well, the reason closer things (and this is just from an aside by my astrophysics teacher in college, we didn't spend a huge amount of time on it) appear to move away at a slower pace is because the space between us is expanding. Thus, when you're far away, there's more space between you and the object, so there is more to expand in between you and thus increase the distance...

Yes, but that means the expansion is constant. For to say that the expansion is accelerating, we should look at the same distance's expansion rate over a long time. Just by saying that the farther galaxies red shifting more, we can't say that the expansion is getting faster. Am I wrong?
Yes, because it's not that the farther galaxies are redshifting more, it's the increase of the rate at which they are redshifted implies the acceleration

2:25 - "We'll never know what that Star, or any other star, looks like at this exact moment".  It's the same for EVERYTHING we view.  Even when I look at my keyboard when I'm typing, I'm looking back in time to how it looked about 1 nano second ago.  That car across the street could have disappeared 50 nano seconds ago, and you wouldn't know about it.  For sure, our brain processing slows things down so much that these times don't really matter, but the undeniable truth of relativity is that everything we see happened a 'short' while ago and we are ALWAYS looking back in time - we see nothing 'as it happens'.  The effect may be more pronounced in space, but don't forget that it happens down here too.  The same laws of physics apply in both cases.

Hamchun Kou It's great that you're reading that text. Have you read the gang of 4 design patterns book or Bjarne Stroustrup's book on the c++language?  They're also compelling reads as well, especially the gang of four text.
ita6aki No I have not read Gang of Four's,but I have plans in reading Bjorne's book as an introduction to C++.Till now I've only finished one book,the one by Eva Tardos,thanks for recommending

Hamchun Kou I don't recommend the Stroustrup book as an introduction to c++ since you'll get introduced to things you really won't need to know immediately.  Perhaps it can serve as something to read when you really need to go that deep.  However the gang of 4 text might blow your mind.  Not because it's a hard read, but because it will get you to rethink every piece of code you've ever written before.  At least it did for me.  Moreover, the head first design patterns are a more straightforward but less broad version of the gang of 4 text.

The delay might mean we see a single point (what does that even mean) at a time, and our mind is too slow to delete the old points from the memory memory that you see (again, I will compare it to computers: it unloads the memory you see to the one in your brain you can remember), so new memory is being added and it looks like you are seeing a lot of things at the same time. For the brain part, you aren't really looking at it from the past, nor the future. It's somewhere in the between, never the present though. I would say it is in the predicted future. Because it takes roughly 0.001 seconds from the signals in your eyes to travel through the brain, so you are looking at it from the past. But because the brain doesn't really want that, it does it's best to create a future image of it, predicting how it would look like on 0.001 seconds, so it's kinda weird about seeing things now. Since it is in the brain's predictable future.
